lesson_learned.headline: OutSystems raised the state of our business with a fast approach, tackling down old issues
lesson_learned.summary:
In the last months, OutSystems has become our primary development tool. Our company is a huge producer of footwear and our development in OutSystems is supporting the construction of a large set of applications in these areas:

Factory and production-level systems (industrial apps)

There are already many applications built to provide information to our offices and for production control of factory processes, simulation, and machine setup. In addition to the already running analytics apps, we are in the process of integrating OutSystems with machines' programmable logic controllers (PLCs). We believe that OutSystems can support factory-level systems that respond quickly. Beginning with the less critical processes, we have already started to build web/mobile applications to be used on the assembly lines and loading docks in the distribution center.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
* Easy and low-code web/mobile development: Reduces the manual labor in compiling and deploying applications and generating procedural code (by reducing development bureaucracy/processes, resulting in real gains). The LifeTime Server approach, requiring just a few steps to publish applications in production environments, is fantastic.

* High reuse of components and business logic: Once built, web/mobile components can be reused in all new developments. In addition, the OutSystems Forge is very useful. We can exchange components and even already-built applications, reducing costs to build specific solutions.

* Build-logic becomes simple with a graphic interface: Developers work better with visual support. In a related vein, we are currently studying if, in the near future, an OutSystems environment could be provisioned to non-technical areas to allow them to construct their own applications (supervised by IT, and with good governance and security assessments).

* Stakeholder engagement and satisfaction: In the past, it was difficult to keep our clients (employees and partners) up to date on the development process. There were many promises of application delivery dates which were often not met. With OutSystems, we can develop and share progress and functionalities.

* Integration: With the SOAP and REST APIs and the database connections allowing communication with different data sources, it’s simple and quick to fulfill requirements which demand resources from multiple sources. In this way, the platform provides opportunities for innovative ideas. A simple example is to check transportation costs against rotes using maps and GPS technologies to measure accurate distances.
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
There are some features expected in the future that may speed up some processes. But there is a lack of development resources that need implementing. For example, OutSystems does not provide any native reporting resources. All reports must be created with other tools or as a webpage. 

Another issue is the asynchronous processing and multithreading tasks for which the current resources of the platform are very generic and not built for the end-user. Any asynchronous jobs have to be constructed with an end-user dashboard to allow inspection of the status of the activities.
lesson_learned.advice:
* When possible, use a cloud environment option rather than a local installation.
* Negotiate a suitable license with OutSystems, taking into account that the application objects grow quickly.
* Hire trainers and make sure the development team sets up a proper architecture. If you choose the wrong approach or do not plan appropriate architecture, in a short time you will certainly have a very large rework. 
* It is essential to build an appropriate Canvas.
* Sometimes, junior developers will perform better with OutSystems, since senior developers often do not adapt to the graphical structural programming. It is not a rule, but some resistance and difficulty of adaptation were noticed.
* A good practice is to hire an expert consulting company, for a couple weeks, which already uses OutSystems. They will help your development team with basic questions, increasing the pace of learning and making it more effective. 
* OutSystems has a set of metadata and any kind of control is possible, but these structures should be practiced with the developers.
OutSystems Forge is a very useful place, when starting out, to download components to adapt to your needs.
* SQL Server is a good default database option for OutSystems. We have never had a problem with it. We recommend using only a single database catalog instead of many.
* Finally, perhaps the most important tip is regarding development governance. Not only for OutSystems but for all types of development, it is very important to maintain normalized and standardized environments. In a chaotic scene with no effort to have periodic reviews, a low-code platform could create a huge mess and the cost will be paid in the near future.

lesson_learned.headline: Implementation is easy, need SPA framework for web platform.
lesson_learned.summary:
Pros:
1. Speed of delivery
2. One click publish - considerably reduces our effort in maintaining versions.
3. Lifetime to move code from one environment to another.
4. Quick learning curve.
5. Mobile development in Breeze and Top-notch mobile patterns available out of box. Almost covering all our requirements
6. Internally uses HP fortify, which highlights the security flaw that we make in our code.
7. Outsystem's proposed 4 layer design helps us to build enterprise level application with less hassle of maintaining dependencies.
8. Integration with other systems is nice and breezy.
9. Debugging from dev/QA box easily.
10. Supports Enterprise framework, re-utilizing the component is a breeze and cross references to the modules are much easier.

Cons:
1.  Inheritance, lamda, generics are all missing which will allow one to implement one simple block instead of rewriting the same piece of code everywhere.
2. Makes it hard to understand the logic compared to traditional programming.
3. Customization of UI components is pain.
4. Basic Client actions are missing and needs to be developed in web platform.
5. SPA framework is not available in Web platform.
6. Good outsystems resource is hard to find.
7. Very few components are available in forge and all are not up-to date.
8. Though outsystems claim abstraction of entities are available by default, In reality if the entities/tables of different module are all stored in one DB, the developer can retrieve data from any entities whether he has permission to view it or not  
.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Build and release is straight forward.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Customization is a real pain.
lesson_learned.advice:
If you are non-technology company and wanted to build applications quickly then Outsystems meets your criteria.
If you want to develop a mobile app with no prior experience of mobile technology, then definitely i would recommend Outsystems.
If you would like to build ground breaking technology and have a wonderful technical team then I would suggest you to continue with your current process.

lesson_learned.headline: Outsystems 11: the upgrade really worths it!
lesson_learned.summary:
Outsystems is agreat platform. I feel 100% comfortable developing web applications with Outsystems. We have been able to deliver applications extremely fast. Now, we are able to spend more time innovating. We have robust and scalable applications.

On the other hand, we have the mobile development. I do believe that it has some opportunity areas but it is getting mature very fast. We have found some errors but the Support team and the RND team are working fast in order to solve them. Despite of all, mobile application delivery is so good. We have speed up mobile application development in more that 60%. We used to spend a lot of time developing Android or IOS applications; now, with Outsystems, we deveolp mobile applications once and we have an installer for two different operation systems.

Update April 16th, 2019
We decided to upgrade our platform to the lastet version (11.0.211.0). The upgrade process took more on those Production Servers whose have more than one Front End Server. Despite of that, I may say that the transition was really smooth and It is worth it because we gained a lot of new awesome features such: micro services, improvement of monitoring and analytics, a lot of new screen templates (web and mobile).
lesson_learned.liked_most:
Is really easy to learn Outsystems. The learning curve is really short. I'm able to ramp up Outsystems developers on really short periods.

The mobile applications are really fast and is easy to push them into Google Play or AppStore because they comply with Industry standards and get authorized really fast.

Regarding web development, is really straight forward. I have not seen a platform with such capabilities.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: I would like that Platform upgrade were even fasters.
lesson_learned.advice: You really need to try it. You can request a POC and, once that you see it, you will surely fall in love.

lesson_learned.headline: Overwhelmed by the speed and possibility's
lesson_learned.summary: Initially the product was developed by outsystems Portugal. I was very positive about the quality of there English. This made communication very easy. The other thing was there devotion to do well. Development was going faster the the users gut handle. I'am happy to see that support in the Netherlands is growing. 10 years ago it was hard to find partners.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
The ability to re-arrange components. 
The you can prototype fast to help users to understand what is going on. 
The way that servicecenter helps out pinpointing potential problems.
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
The fact that all data is in One database.
 I know that OS11 will separate its logging, but i think that the userdata should also be separated.
 I would like to see a linux version of service studio.
lesson_learned.advice:
The biggest (Still) problem is convincing our traditional developers.
A new custom should make sure that the it department embrace this platform.   
Prepare there organisation for an other way of delivering apps then they are used.

vendors_considered: I was more the 10 years ago and before mi time with the company

additional_context.version_number: 9.0 Currently working on the upgrade to 10 / 11

lesson_learned.headline: OutSystems's tool has delivered consistently and the company has supported us well.
lesson_learned.summary: OutSystems provide a very capable tool that has allowed us to engineer a product that has become a core business asset. In a world where unicorns are hard to find, we have a tool that has allowed us to pull one out of a hat regularly to save the day.  We have worked with OutSystems now for a number of years and they have become part of our team.  They have supported us on our journey and have even become a customer of ours!  The experience has been very good.
lesson_learned.liked_most: There is little that cannot be done within the tool.  You will hear developers complain that their skills are being diluted but quickly our team embraced the technology and it is now the goto tool for all solutions.
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
Personally it is the license pricing is based on the amount of code developed and used in production.  You have a quota of Application Objects.  This adds an artificial annoyance when building releases when you are close to limits.  You may need to release code before deprecating the system it is making redundant, and you don't want to be spending on extra licensing to achieve this.

However, the flip side is that you become very aggressive about deprecating code and cleaning up redundancy - which is a good thing.  We also insist on making sure there is a decent ROI on development. So, although disliked, there is a positive to this negative.
lesson_learned.advice: Licensing and budgeting costs is probably the thing to keep an eye on.
lesson_learned.do_differently: The journey has been good with OutSystems and with hidsight the choices of what we developed would be different, not how we developed them.

integration_deployment.technologies:
We integrated a number of external services such as credit card payments, e-voucher and e-card purchasing.  We also sell cinema tickets and other discounts though integrations with third parties. 

We also have SSO via SAML and Azure from numerous sources into our product and going out to others.   

We are integrated with NAV.  We are also looking at deeper integration into company payroll systems. 

OutSystems has allowed us to quickly build these integrations - usually quicker than the other side has taken to talk about it!

lesson_learned.headline: The only platform required for Enterprise Applications
lesson_learned.summary:
Worked well:
When it comes to building internal/enterprise applications, OutSystems excels and there is no need consider traditional development(using code). OutSystems team thought well about the end to end process meaning development, deployment & monitoring. CRUD applications are piece of cake with OutSystems.

Didn't work well:
When it comes to customization, developers might have issues. Custom CSS and Logic  is manageable in OutSystems, when it comes to write own JavaScript code, things start to get complicated. Although it can be achieve, the time spent is considerably high. Some case it might be easier to develop using code.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
-OutSystems Support team is really helpful. Very fast, knowledgeable and friendly.
-Ease of developing CRUD application. Bootstrap feature available for Entities really make it easy to develop applications.
-Deployment and Monitoring. Ease of moving apps from one environment to another and a good monitoring tool make it easy for the support team
-Built in UI. There is no need to spend time to setup the UI framework, the out of the box one has a decent look and feel.
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
-Customization is still quite difficult. Especially writing JavaScript, need to publish the entire solution just to test a small part.
-Lack of versioning for libraries. It will be good to have versioning for libraries so each application can use the library it needs when going to production. Otherwise, applications need to be pushed to production due to a library change. This might be troublesome.
-Version control, it will be nice to have branching so there could be parallel development track and merging once all are done.
lesson_learned.advice:
People need to understand the strengths and weakness and the issue the platform is trying to solve. Many people (whom i have worked with) have a misconception that OutSystems is a front end tool. With this approach, there will be lot of problems because APIs will be built in another platform then it will be consumed by OutSystems. With this approach, OutSystems is not being used at its full potential.

OutSystems should be used  end to end (front-end and backend) and it only excels when used in that manner. Try your best to do everything using the out of the box functionalities, if customization is required then be prepared to spend some time.

lesson_learned.headline: Let's us go faster than the business is ready for
lesson_learned.summary: OutSystems has allowed us to deliver applications at a pace faster than the business can request/define them.  We have been working with the OutSystems Enablement Team and have built our applications such that they are mobile ready, so that our customers can have a great mobile experience once we complete the web experience.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The platform is truly a high productivity tool which allows us to solve significantly more business problems than we could with traditional development.  OutSystems' training is very well put together, easy to access, and up to date.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: In some cases, I miss writing code.  OutSystems delivers on exactly what it promises.
lesson_learned.advice: Do your best to separate writing code from solving business problems and you will go far.

lesson_learned.headline: From idea to business recognised by the top 6 major oil companies in less than 12 months
lesson_learned.summary: Outsystems offered us an incredible time to value of less than 12 months. I have developed web based systems for more than 20 years but I have not seen anything like it before in my life. Outsystems also proved to be a very reliable and consistently high quality platform.
lesson_learned.liked_most: I like the completeness of the tools for developing and IT ops. Most platforms tend to focus on the development only but the costs are really in IT ops. The other thing is that the available documentation is always of a very high quality standard. And last but not least, the scalability and agility it offers us is best of breed.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: The subscription price is about the only thing I can think of.
lesson_learned.advice: The choice for a low code platform is not nothing to take lightly. You will need to live with that choice for years. We choose Outsystems over other platforms despite of the initial worries of vendor lockin and costs. They proved to offer us an incredible increase of time to value, agility and robustness which comes with a multiply of their relatively high subscription price.

lesson_learned.headline: Learn fast, develop faster.
lesson_learned.summary: Using OutSystems reduced the time we develop applications greatly. The low code platform provides developers with no background in developing Outsystems learn it very fast. The youtube tutorial videos helped a lot.
lesson_learned.liked_most: It provides the developers with the tool to create applications fast. Most of the things that you need multiple lines of code using other languages would just be in seconds using OutSystems. The community is also very helpful with providing help or solutions to problems encountered.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: The applications would get slower to publish when it has more dependencies which would be hard to avoid especially when it is a large application. Coding standards are also not that popular. Having multiple users publishing in the same module is also confusing because of the UI being used to merge updates.
lesson_learned.advice: Have users have a sandbox first to be able to get familiar with the product. It would also be great if users are given enough time to learn as most developers are not familiar with low code platforms. Get users to be certified developers and then make them teach new users.

lesson_learned.headline: Fast, robust application development that suits our needs
lesson_learned.summary: We were looking for a system to standardise our software development, with source control and easy deployment. Outsystems have given us this, with help along the way.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The speed with which we can produce minimum viable product of an application.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: A decent reporting/BI module would be nice.
lesson_learned.advice: Once you've got over the build an application in five minutes demo, which is pretty impressive, always think about the data structures. Make sure that your internal developers are sold on the use of the platform, they will be the ones using it, and although it is low-code it still suits a developer type mindset.

general_info.review_source: Invited by Gartner (email, event, account rep)

lesson_learned.headline: Easy Implementation, Great relationship with Supplier, Easy to use
lesson_learned.summary: Great supplier relationship, not always chasing for additional revenue, superb support, easy platform to implement and use.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Most elements we require are available straight out of the box. If you need to think too hard, then you are doing something wrong. Makes an average developer into a great developer!
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Support for our chosen implementation (Java/Oracle) is being removed and hence we will be strongly encouraged to migrate to a .NET/SQL stack within the next 2 years.
lesson_learned.advice: Give it a try and don't carry broken processes with you. Take an opportunity to open your minds to the possible. If it doesn't work out as you expect, then throw what you have built away and start again - it's quicker and easier than trying to fix something which doesn't work as you want (I call this disposable IT).

lesson_learned.headline: Excellent LowCode solution enabling high quality development
lesson_learned.summary: Outsystems are attentive but not aggressive in their approach. We have formed excellent relationships with Outsystems at a personal and professional level. Easy to use intiative product which has excellent supporting training material
lesson_learned.liked_most: Very workable IDE and the fully integrated environment, along with Lifetime and platform health analytics all combine to make a very robust and very usable solution
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Our implementation is in the Cloud on AWS, and is managed by Outsystems on our behalf. On the very rare occasions we have the need for  quick turnaround of issues or responses sometimse I feel that the feedback we get is not timely. This isn't to say that they are not actively looking at our issues, but on occasion we have had to chase a response. This may be a little overcritical as the vast majority of our interactions are excellent
lesson_learned.advice:
Buy it!
However,  carefully look at how you want to manage your platform/infrastructure, whether you want to completely off load the support to OutSystems or manage it yourselves. Outsystems support is excellent but you will have more flexibility and control if you want to manage it with your own team.

lesson_learned.headline: almost fully grown
lesson_learned.summary: Worked with OS 10, There is a LOT that is amazing about the product but mostly in the UX there are some small point that could make developing faster. Since the presentation for 11 Iºve already seen a lot of improvenets, but mostly Iºm talking about walking through UI with keyboard. Functionality Is very good altough the latest versions of 10 caused a lot of crashes with me.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The ease of use is really good and the logic of the application itself is nicely seperated. What I sometimes do miss is expanded documentation on the possibility of some functions or functionality.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: No possibility to customize the interface is a something i really miss. Even though keeping everything in the same place and being consistent may be a good thing. I really would like to see a customizable workspace like for example Adobe has on their products.
lesson_learned.advice: Outsystems is the next step in programming like c came before c++. It takes little time getting used to the system and way of working. Also it brings together all people of different disciplines. Which eliminates a lot of waste. If you have the budget then this is the only way to go

lesson_learned.headline: Succesfull co-development of our Core application landscape
lesson_learned.summary:
The collaboration on a personal level between the teams worked really well. Also the  Outsystems development teams buiding our applications were/are productive. Outsystems covered the development when we were not  up to speed yet with their own DEvOps teams. The platform is stable and intuiteve and OutSystems regulary offers new capabilities. (Like rusted Advisor, monitoring silutions). 
Isseus we faced were in the security of the platform connecting to our legacy ESB. Also OUtSsytems Paas does not include the  Autoscaling possiblities of AWS. Other issues is that we introduced some technical Debt during the  time that OutSystems was in the  lead for  Development of our applications. That Technical Debt should have been managed better by both OutSsystems and us.
lesson_learned.liked_most: It (almost) never breaks
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Dababase access, SoD of AWS access

lesson_learned.headline: State of the art RAD platform, that's easy to integrate into your current IT landscape
lesson_learned.summary: Outsystems has developed a platform that allows companies to keep up with ever increasing demands. It allows you to adapt to changing market demands quickly. The only negative thing about it is the licensing model; i.e. it's hard to know in front what the licensing cost will be because of the AO's. That could lead to bad architectural choices to reduce cost..>
lesson_learned.liked_most: Outsystems is easy to integrate into your current IT landscape and although developers tend to be a little sceptical in the beginning they turn around real quick. It allows us to move much faster, implementing POC's as well as entreprise grade applications.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: The licensing model. Versioning in comparison to git, subversion, stuff like that
lesson_learned.advice: Start small, learn your lessons, before you do a full scale project

integration_deployment.implementation_strategy: Worked with both the vendor and 3rd-party service providers

lesson_learned.headline: Easy to learn, intuitive and very supportive!
lesson_learned.summary: Starting without any former IT experience, I began working with OutSystems about 7 months ago. I first did the online course to learn the basics and then actually started building our new application - with the help of some developers with more experience. OutSystems is so easy in its use that even someone with no developing experience like me is able to actually build an application that is usefull. I'm still learning every day, but that's only fun with this intuitive platform. OutSystems (and its community) is very supportive, giving us new features every few weeks and actually listening to their customers. I'm really satisfied.
lesson_learned.liked_most: What I like most is the intuitive ease of use. One does not have to have any experience to be able to use OutSystems in a basic way. OutSystems gives suggestions and when I'm struggling finding the right solution, there's always the support-option and the community to help me out.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: As I said, I have no previous experience with developing software. Now to a certain extend this is no real problem using OutSystems. But there are some points in the software, where there is some coding-experience or -knowledge is assumed. This is understandable, of course, but for me not always usefull.
lesson_learned.advice: Go for it! Try to get some developers with experience and combine them in a team with junior engineers.

lesson_learned.headline: One of the best RAD softwares in the market. You can make a simple application in a snap
lesson_learned.summary: Outsystems released a top of the notch product. It allows anyone to build a good and solid application within minutes. This RAD software overcame many difficulties during its development but they've reached a nice and stable version of the platform. This software also offers many other useful tools such as Service Center (to monitor the application) and Lifetime.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The way it simplifies any developers life. With Outsystems (and its products) you can, not only, build but also deploy, monitor and integrate any of your applications. The fast development it's definitely its best feature.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: The software still has some constraints and bugs that should be fixed. The number of critical errors during development in the service studio still is one of my main concerns.
lesson_learned.advice: The fast development will surprise any developer, specially the ones from more "traditional" technologies like JAVA, PHP or .NET.

lesson_learned.headline: Low code platform has increased speed and quality of overall Product development
lesson_learned.summary:
This low code platform has helped us deliver more applications  of a consistent high quality, on time and on budget.
The platform also makes it easy for new developers to jump right in and work immediately.
The training material and online forums has also been an excellent resource for everyone.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
Its ease of use, very easy to learn and become proficient .
There is also a lot of pre- built web blocks available on the Forge
lesson_learned.disliked_most: the version control needs a little bit of work in extreme case where multiple users are working on the exact web block.
lesson_learned.advice: Introduce more staff members earlier

lesson_learned.headline: Digital Transformation, the easy way
lesson_learned.summary:
Outsystems provides a powerful platform for digital transformation development, making it easier to implement digital processes and experiences for end costumers / users.
They focus in large enterprise customers, having a big price tag for small size companies, even thought they do have a free offer.
They should consider to package the product for small companies, making available to all the amazing competitive power that the platform offers.
lesson_learned.liked_most: How easy it is to develop, integrate, extend, and deliver SW across devices.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Not having it available to small companies. This could explode outsystems market and help the modernization and growth of small companies.
lesson_learned.advice:
Find a good diverse team to develop your apps.
Think architecture long term.
Be aware of all the costs regarding outsystems usage.
Use their cloud offering.

lesson_learned.headline: Easy to understand and integrate and lots of components and tools to create a great sites
lesson_learned.summary:
While working on one of the client project, we had a great experience working with outsystems developers and architects, they understood our requirements and helped us in designing the things right at first place.  
Course provided by out-systems are easy to understand with examples and lot of exercises. This will prepare us for next level to take up new challenges.
Within 24 hours response to the problem.
Outsystems provides all kinds of widgets and also have forge components to integrate with existing system.
I feel great to work with outsystems to create web and mobile app.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
I learned Mobile development very quickly and started contributing to project.
Faster delivery and change cycles.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: As of now, I started liking it, it is fulfilling all I need it.

lesson_learned.headline: Easy to use tool for building applications, though with an intransparent price model.
lesson_learned.summary:
Outsystems is easy to learn and use and has several features that accelerates the development of applications. Building applications is very visual (hence low-code) and 'what you see is what you get'.
The setup of the price model is not very transparent at first, because it's based on Application Objects (AOs) and it's hard to estimate the needed AOs for an application. It stimulates building complexer apps than needed (e.g. putting several features on one page behind complex logics, to reduce the amount of AOs for the application).
lesson_learned.liked_most: Outsystems offers several templates and components out of the box for building up a page very quickly. Setup of workflows and logic is very visual.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Outsystems needs additional features to support working with large and/or complex data models. Now it's hard sometimes to keep overview.
lesson_learned.advice: If self building applications isn't common in your organization, I'd advise to contract a consultancy partner to help with development, agile working and applying best practices.
lesson_learned.do_differently: Our IT department wasn't ready to connect the cloud based Outsystems to our network and on premise applications. If we could start over, we would take (more) preparations for this connection.

lesson_learned.headline: Low code rapid development platform
lesson_learned.summary: I have been working on this product for an year now. I have worked for customers on enterprise applications using Outsystems platform. I would like to say that Outsystems is Low code rapid development platform. Its is amaze to see the spike in productivity and ready to market in very less time than compare to the traditional web application development.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
Easy to implement applications with limited coding language knowledge.
Visual development
Rapid development
Easy to manage applications
Continuous deployment
Customer Service from Outsystems is outstanding.
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
I am facing issue when dealing with Time zone based data retrieve.
Working on AR application is kind of pain.
Rarely my environment hangs.
lesson_learned.advice: Outsystems is a way ahead with Low code platform. The tools and platform provided by Outsystems is very easy to adopt by the developer and hence can really develop amazing applications in reduced time.

This is not ' Magic Wand', but accelerate application development speed.

lesson_learned.headline: Great journey with Outsystems
lesson_learned.liked_most: You can develop and implement changes very fast. Integration possibility with other apps are huge.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: We have launched 3rd app developed on Outsystems and 4th one is on the way. As the app number increase dependencies go high and it is becoming more complex to manage the deployments.

lesson_learned.headline: Great product with huge potential to disrupt many markets
lesson_learned.summary: Overall Outsystems meets all need of an enterprise to build custom and fit-for-purpose applications. Allows us to be very lean and spend our time reviewing the company's processes rather than reviewing the code itself.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The ability of retain business rules maintaining the ability to shift the technology stack we develop in. That creates a great sense of tranquility that the technology will not be obsolete anytime soon.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Licensing model, doesn't allow for small businesses, which prevents us developers from doing more free lancing and small developments to boost the small and micro companies into becoming large and enterprise companies.
lesson_learned.advice: Make sure you understand the licensing model you are getting in, make sure you have a strong vision for your company and hire the best skills you can afford. If you're looking for a cheap way to use this solution you won't take the maximum benefits from the product and/or service.

lesson_learned.headline: A lot of speed for process automization with high usability apps
lesson_learned.summary: We have been using Outsystems for enterprise wide rapid application platform. Integrations have been easy. Legacy user interfaces have been replaced with new mobile and web applications.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Learning curve has been quick for developers to learn how to use platform. Using product is Intuitive and logicical. Our developers love Outsysystems. Productivity and speed is amazing
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Minor things need improvements. Sometimes development environment is slow. It is annoying to install new versions of service studio.
lesson_learned.advice: Consider making a proof of concept befor choosing the right product. Pay intension on design and usability. When using Outsystems for rapid application development, bottleneck in development cycle is not (low)coding, usually design and concept development takes more time and resources.

integration_deployment.implementation_strategy: Worked with both the vendor and 3rd-party service providers

lesson_learned.headline: Low code development is the bait but Enterprise  grade deployment and management is what h
lesson_learned.summary: The Outsystems  platform is the perfect ecosystem for developing bot quick RAD applications as well as large, longer running enterprise grade systems. We are in the process of a 5 year project to migrate a 30 year old product with millions of lines of code over to the platform. Beyond the low code RAD development there is an excellent and robust deployment an monitoring systems that goes beyond what most traditional development systems provide.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
Unlike most low code environment Outsystems still lets you get down into full .net or Java extensions to help make up for any shortcomings of the low code system. It does have some inflexibilities, but these are to force less experienced developers to follow best practive, more experienced developers should be able to workaround most of the restrictions 

Good points
Low code
Fast for new developers to come onboard
Good database functionality
Excellent security and results from penetration testing
Full Development, testing and Production environments with excellent deployment system
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
Not the best version control system but workable, no branching

Not object orientated so reduces code re-usability to some degree but does have ability to share code, web screens and web blocks between applications.

Whilst it does allow less experienced developers to be productive quicker and with less errors it does not replace the need for at least some development and platform knowledge

High Price
lesson_learned.advice: If you need a solid system with a good product development and deployment lifecycle then this is a great product to use. On the other hand if you want a cheap development and hosting platform then this is probably outside your price range.

lesson_learned.headline: Powerful, enterprise-grade low-code tool that speeds time-to-market!
lesson_learned.summary: Great tool for building web and mobile applications quickly!  In addition to speedier app dev, the deployment process is very streamlined, handling both code and data pushes across environments, while supporting non-destructive rollback of software releases.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Ease of constucting responsive web and mobile application UI's.  Minimal need for tweaking CSS/HTML/Javascript means that new javascript frameworks can be supported by the platform in the future with little to no re-factoring/coding.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Some nice-to-have features are lacking, such as the ability to define database "views" within the platform itself, to abstract away complexity.  The IDE also takes some time to get used to, but otherwise is very powerful.
lesson_learned.advice: I recommend taking advantage of the Customer Success Program, which grants access to master classes and allocates time to meet with Outsystems professionals to review code, ask detailed questions, etc.

additional_context.deployment_scale: Specific divisions, regions, or business units

lesson_learned.headline: Not quite citizen developer panacea, but an excellent force multiplier for a small team
lesson_learned.summary:
Low code development platform as a service.  Does what it says on the tin.  While no product has attained that complete 'citizen developer' nirvana, Outsystems is definitely a solid product, and a good force multiplier for an existing development team.  

We found UI development to be exceptionally speedy, and DevOps processes were quite streamlined as well.  Application logic development still sometimes required hand writing code on the backend, but the ability to easily integrate with XML or RESTful services made that a nonissue.  Once our developers climbed the learning curve with Outsystems, they were able to churn out good looking, branded, and functional UI at a blistering pace.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Built in templates and branding capabilities let a capable user create a fully branded UI in very short order.  Able to create extremely professional looking and attractive user experiences in a very short amount of time.  Designing and building systems is simple enough in this tool that non-technical people have a fighting chance at building something useful.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Lack of rich architectural examples in the available training materials.  Had to trial and error our first effort a few times until we figured out a proper reusable and decoupled application architecture.
lesson_learned.advice: While it is one of the best low-code tools I've worked with, having a technical resource that is conversant with web development is a huge boon.  Outsystems definitely files a lot of the sharp edges off of web development, but you will have the most success using it as a force multiplier for an existing development team.

lesson_learned.liked_most: That there is a lot of online training that can help new users get started.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Because it's easy to drag and drop bubbles, people can easily fall into the trap of poor practices.  Just because you can easily drag aggregates on the screen doesn't mean you should.  I believe that a development background is still very important to have optimized solutions.
lesson_learned.advice: Make sure you have the right development team

Indirectly, it streamlines and standardizes the code which reduces the fragmentation of code and introduction of developers personalities and preferences in the code. lesson_learned.headline: Outsystems a joy to devolop applications

It is very user friendly and quick to develop and modify to user's  needs. And very intuitive to work with for developers as well as users of the implemented applications.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Outsystems is easy to use, quite quick to learn.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: You need to use the mouse a lot while developing in Outsystems. I had some rsi problems for some time.
lesson_learned.advice: Start using Outsystems. It is very efficient product. You're customers and or users will be pleased to be using it.

lesson_learned.headline: Development and deployment made superfast.
lesson_learned.summary: When we think about Low code development, first thing comes in my mind is Outsystems. Outsystems is a very good low code platform to build applications, manage applications. Now anyone can develop application fast and efficient.
lesson_learned.liked_most: I like outsystems very much because of its simplicity of developing an Application. Anyone can build Web/Mobile application without prior knowledge of intense coding.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: When it comes to plugins outsystems lacks a bit. suppose i want to integrate VISA payment gateway, i can't find any plugin for this anywhere. so i think if outsystems build more plug ins that would be helpful.
lesson_learned.advice: Outsystems is the best Low Code platform you will find out there.
lesson_learned.do_differently: Yes, Instead of using old technologies to build application, we will be able to use Outsystems and will deliver application faster and efficiently.

lesson_learned.headline: Easy and fast implementation for most basic stuff.
lesson_learned.summary: Programming with this low-code platform has been fairly faster and easier than conventional methods, albeit some minor UX issues.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Deployments are very easy to make.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Debugging options should be improved (i.e. debugging in .NET extensions, hot-swapping variable values during debugging). Licensing could also be more fair for countries that have a weak currency (35K € / year may not seem high in Western Europe, but it is for many other countries.)
lesson_learned.advice: If your pojects do not require a lot of detailed front-end representations and connections to external services, OutSystems is fairly easy and fast to create brand new applications.

lesson_learned.headline: Fast and easy to develop, but needs improvement in performance (parallel widget loading)
lesson_learned.summary:
We managed to deliver 1 business critical application in a very reasonable time using Outsystems platform . 
- Quick and fast development compared to traditional application dev 
- Very easy to manage the changes , specially for UI level 
- Integrating with UI with API using this platform is seamless
lesson_learned.liked_most:
- faster and easy development  
- API/WS integration with UI is effortless 
- modular approach makes it easy to fix bugs in respective bugs 
- Lifetime is nice way to manage deployment and saves lot of efforts 
- Detailed logging in Service center
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
- version management . It is very difficult to push just a some portion of the code . There is no branching feature . It needs lot of efforts to manually do version control or manage deployments in such cases 
- in our use case , we experienced performance issues due sequential widget loading. Platform should have option to bring in parallel widget loading
lesson_learned.advice: - If you are looking for quick turnaround development platform then Outsystems is the one to go for. However be watchful and consider performance challenges for your use case .

lesson_learned.headline: Awesome low code platform with incredible time to market
lesson_learned.summary: I have almost 10 years of software development with Outsystems. I've started in Outsystems 5.0 version and developed projects across multiple industries like Banking, Health, Insurance along the years.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
The platform provides fast deliver and time to market. It's easily to use and to integrate with any system.
Has multiple tools as Service Center, which provides a management console for error/integration/email logging, configuration and analytics; Lifetime which provides staging across multiple environments, users, teams and roles management and performance monitor.
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
The license costs are very high. Makes impossible to small companies to use.
Could have a license model which the client pays a fee for each user that uses the application. The plataform only supports a database server which is a scalability problem for enterprise grade solutions.
lesson_learned.advice: Outsystems it's the best choice.

lesson_learned.headline: Outsystems into the future

lesson_learned.liked_most: The visual aspect of code writing.  It's self documenting and other developers and edit code easily if it wasn't written by them.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: We are new to developing in Outsystems so it has been good to us so far.
lesson_learned.advice: Really think about the use of OUtsystems for your future.  If you expect to use your internal data base, you may want an on premises install vs. the cloud.

lesson_learned.headline: Easy to use product for rapid application development
lesson_learned.summary: Product is very easy to get started with. Provides an easy-to-use interface for rapid application development. Customer support has been great, and all companies that I personally have spoken to have loved the tool.
lesson_learned.liked_most: This product is very easy to pick up and use out of the box. It provides a clean interface for rapid application development and the customer support has been excellent.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Some of the configuration for an enterprise company can take a little while. However, this can be the case for most cloud products that are used at the enterprise level. Seems to be par for the course in this regard.
lesson_learned.advice: Try to carve out some time with your internal teams that handle security and networking for the set up of a VPN and LDAP integration if you plan on going with the cloud option. This will save a lot of back-and-forth between the team leading the integration, Outsystems support, and your internal security and networking teams.

The thing that i would like to see changed is the deployment process. Since liftetime only allows you to push changes from dev --> Test --> UAT --> prod it is sometimes hard to fix issues reported during UAT.

Speed of developing
Multiplatform app development
Outsystems support during the startup phase (Customer Success Program)

lesson_learned.advice: Before move to outsystems, evaluate your capacity to convert or attract developers. It is very easy to train new developers when they have .net skills however, some markets are really volatile to retain talents.

lesson_learned.headline: Speed and quality are what's important, and OutSystems allows us to have both
lesson_learned.summary: It's been a great overall experience.  Been using OutSystems for 5 years and couldn't be happier.  We'll be using it well into the future for both our business web applications and future mobile applications.
lesson_learned.liked_most: All the boiler-plate processes are automated and don't need to be worried about.  It's awesome!
lesson_learned.disliked_most: That the IDE doesn't run with each open project doesn't run as a separate process, and/or it's still a 32 bit application.  The biggest problem is memory issues along with performance.  The overall architecture of the IDE needs to be updated.
lesson_learned.advice: Determine if it would be more advantageous to your company to either hire on 2-4 more developers to alleviate the backlog, or sign up for OutSystems minus those 2-4 more employees. It's that efficient.

lesson_learned.headline: Development is rapid, provided that you have available services or API's
lesson_learned.summary: OutSystems is a platform with which you can develop apps quickly and OutSystems 11 looks very promissing. The forge is powerful as are the SilkUI templates. The one thing we realized developing an app with OutSystems, is that development is rapid only when you have a pool of microservices or API's available. Maybe this is a no brainer for some, but as we were not used to writing services or API's, these had to be developed as well during development of the app.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The ability to quickly create a prototype for an app. For users, a prototype is much clearer than a written document of how the app will work. Also, all the hard work you had to do in the past, is taken out of your hands.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: The standard screens and functionality of an app can quickly be developed, but the things that make an app suited for your company, the business logic, still needs some more work.

lesson_learned.headline: The toolset for materializing business value
lesson_learned.summary: OutSystems allows good solution architectures to quickly come to life and support ever evolving business needs, providing and efficient way to continuously add value to the business.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The ability to quickly bring to life solutions for business challenges is outstanding.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: OutSystems is a victim of it's own growth, with limited market offering for developers and support engineers.
lesson_learned.advice: OutSystems does not replace architects and tech leads. A sound architecture is mandatory. OutSystems "only" provides the means to bring solutions based on that architecture to life in a predictable way.

lesson_learned.disliked_most:
The pricetag on the product. It would be very useful for smaller vendors to use the platform and create smaller applications all around the world.

lesson_learned.advice: If you do make the transfer to Outsystems, motivate your people and remember that the longer you work with the platform, the more you'll have to pay.

lesson_learned.headline: Outsystems - The next big thing in Digital Transformation
lesson_learned.summary: Outsystems offers a complete, enterprise-proven platform that best lives up to the promise of low-code development. With its unbeatable speed, it has proved to be a game changer in developing edge applications. Compared to traditional web development technologies, where development would go on months or even years, Outsystems has clearly brought in the difference in time as well as effort. The capabilities that this platform has to offer has created a huge buzz among the various businesses in the organization and is being considered as the #1 low code platform for digital transformation. Everyone wants to take the Leap to Outsystems.
lesson_learned.liked_most: It's an easy to use product that comes with a whole lot of exciting features. The full stack visual development and reusable functionality between application modules make the life of a developer a helluva lot easier. The In-App feedback feature allows the user to share written feedback right inside the application and makes for a great user experience.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: It's been a great experience so far. Difficult to answer at the moment

lesson_learned.headline: Great RAD platform, one that really works, without compromises on features or integration
lesson_learned.summary: Everything about the platform seems to be well thought of from the start. From the moment you begin learning and using it you find each new thing you learn about it is something that works as you would expect: 1-click deploy really works, and so does environment promotion (development to quality to production), even for database changes. Refactoring is a bliss: whatever the platform can help you there, it will. Overall, it completely takes your attention out of the low-level technical issues (files, scripts, upgrades, lifecycle, ...), so you can focus only on features and code. The main drawback is the granularity of the source code: when you want to promote something between environments, the smallest thing you can promote is a whole module. When you have several features being developed on the same module, with different lifecycles, you have to manage really well how you promote only some of them to production. When you want to reuse code, a mesh of references between modules start to appear, and promoting a single feature, that envolves several modules, each with several features being developed, makes promotion to production take some time, mainly on coordinating all development teams for a "safe" promotion to production.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Very easy to learn, to start using and creating applications and features. Write a "Hello World", deploy, and use.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Granularity of the promotable code between environments: only whole modules can be promoted.
lesson_learned.advice: Sign up to an outsystems account, download the IDE, create a hello world screen and deploy it on the free cloud environment. See how easy it is. Than learn how to use it through the videos (really "do" the classes and the programming, don't just stare at the screen watching the videos), and in 3 days you will be able to make complete applications (from database to pretty front-ends), web or mobile.

lesson_learned.headline: Great for applications managing data
lesson_learned.summary: OutSystems is a great tool for certain use cases. When building an application for managing data, especially in B2B and B2E environments, it really enables to build an application faster. B2C more web development comes in play.
lesson_learned.liked_most: The work which is taken out of the hands of the developer where in a more traditional development environment a lot of time is spend.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Not having an "advanced mode" in which choices made by OutSystems can be overridden. I.e. there is an old jQuery version used as basis for the front-end and there is no way to properly replace it.
lesson_learned.advice: Think about the type of application you would like to build and if it fits with what OutSystems is good at; data manipulation. If a lot of (visual) customization is needed, this might not be the tool for you.

lesson_learned.headline: Development is easy but still needs improvement for working on highly complex applications
lesson_learned.summary:
What worked well - Time required to build any application using Outsystems was very less as compared to other technologies. Most of the things like logger, database configurations, authentication and authorization was almost readily available in Outsystems you just need to use it correctly. Additionally I am very satisfied with community answers, they were really helpful. Debugging is also one of great feature provided by Outsystems, this work seamlessly. 
What needs to improved - Outsystems is like one box where you will easily implement things if those are available in that box, if your application needs very heavy javascript support then this will be little tricky, code maintenance will be difficult. If you want your application with some Javascript then you will be benefited with this. JS code editors are not well, those don't provide any intellisence while coding application, need lot improvement here. Finding application error after deploying it in stack trace is little complicated.
lesson_learned.liked_most: Community support is good.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: JS Editors.
lesson_learned.advice: Go for it if you want to time market but keep in mind that if your application needs heavy javascript support then maintenance would go little on higher side.

lesson_learned.summary: They have supported us through our Digitization journey by bringing in their Low Code platform. So far we have received excellent support from them, hoping to continue the same in the future as well.
lesson_learned.liked_most:
The ease of development as compared to traditional custom development technologies.
The ability to standardize the look and feel of all the applications that you build on this platform.
The connectors with different ERP's which are readily available.
The ease of incorporating changes in your existing application.
The ability to monitor the performance of applications proactively instead of waiting for the application to go down and then troubleshoot.
lesson_learned.disliked_most:
Not enough UI components. For example we wanted to create a Gantt Chart view in one of our applications which was supposed to be actionable and interactive but was not available.
Some more features to enable creation of small reporting applications.
lesson_learned.advice:
In case you are looking to utilize this platform for internal edge applications and are not looking at creating ERP's or Content Management systems, its a great place to start.
Also ensure that you use the advanced application  monitoring features that come with the platform.

lesson_learned.liked_most: We belive this is a magic tool for us. Everything about it is really great. The product has changed life of many prefessionals. The productivity level, the interest, excitment etc. of our IT delivery team are showing upward trends. This is very exciting for us as we are now delivring high quality apps very quickly to our end users.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Service - It will be good if Outsystems focuses on delivering Low Code apps in lower price by engaging low cost partners. It is important as it will help their new clients to quickly realize the value of their platfrom. Which in turn will also help their clients to make a mind shit (the cultural change in the IT delivery team) they need to bring in fast to realize the potentional of this platfrom and become efficient and self sufficient.
lesson_learned.advice:
By signing Outsystems just does not mean you are introducing a new technology where you can deliver fast applications. It is also important to understand that we need to bring in a cultural change in the way we develop and deliver apps which is very closely tied with this platfrom capability. The faster you realize and come out of traditional mode of development the better it is. 
With strong ALM built in with the platfrom, the ability to build and maintain UX style guides and reusable components etc. it is important to understand that if we as a delivery team do not change and bring in the governance etc. to align with the platform capability, then irrespective of the technology we choose, it will be a failure. Will be easy for us to blame the technology and not the people (who are actualy the real culprit)

lesson_learned.headline: Industry leader but pricing focuses on large enterprises
lesson_learned.liked_most: Easy to implement, extreme short time to market, great customisation, programmers without OS experience are able to add value after one week of training, etc.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: Over the recent years, OutSystems got more focused on the larger enterprise accounts. Given our strong relationship (we employ 2 out of 31 OutSystems MVP programmers and we are the main supplier of platform bugs etc., do most of the referal visits for new customers in the Benelux etc.) we were able to reach an attractive contract pricing which suits the size of our company (120m euro revenues, 130 employees, i.e. SME). Reaching the end of the current contract by the end of 2018 I decided to reach out to OS to already see whether we could extent the contract given we have developed litterally all our systems in OS (except for financial bookkeeping, etc.) and hence the crucial role for our business. OS didn't want to extent if we would not increase our contract directly for the next quarter. After not agreeing to this proposal they send an offer in which we should double the current pricing by the next quarter (which started by receipt of this proposal in 3 working days...) and if we would not agree they would cancel the current contract directly after the end of the contract period. I must admit I never experienced a one-sided canceling of the contract from the supplier. In light of our relationship we are astonished and received similar stories from community, especially from smaller companies which do a lot in OS.
lesson_learned.advice: A lot to say about implementation, culture change, etc. But what we hear from the community smaller companies got in a squeeze with OS' pricing model after a few years. Please to this into account when starting your relationship.

lesson_learned.headline: Low-code and feature rich system allowed for experimentation, iteration to great product
lesson_learned.liked_most: The ability to adjust, be agile works.  The business doesn't alway know what they really want.  Or, what the want turns out to not be helpful after all.  To implement something quickly allows you to fail fast where you need to abandon an effort so that you can experiment in areas that turn out to be significant.
lesson_learned.disliked_most: The product is powerful.  Human nature provides the most challenging concerns.  For example, sometimes programmers want to know all the facts but they are not yet knowable.  Or, you want to change things which means tearing down what you just built.  To mitigate this, I continually remind the team about the value of being agile and delivering something noone even knew they wanted until they started down the path.  The business also has issues in this area.  They are not used to moving this fast and maybe everyone is not eager for change.  Managing the overall process of change is the most challenging part.
lesson_learned.advice: Be prepared to move more quickly than you ever have.  Maintaining a backlog of stories to implement is necessary to keep the programmers busy.
